title: Two Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.
content:
Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.

Over the first decade and a half of my career in design, I’ve worked in a variety of positions across multiple industries in a range of companies. So when I was offered the position of Creative Director at Workfront, I thought I was ready. I was confident that my experience as a designer had prepared me for the role I was about to step into.

Within a couple of weeks on the job, I came to a gut-punch realization: I was not ready. I was SO not ready. Not because I didn’t know my craft—but because I mistakenly believed that the craft was all I needed.

I’m speaking at Adobe MAX in November about some of the painful lessons I’ve learned over the last four years working as a Creative Director in a presentation called “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

My aim is to give the presentation that I wish someone had given to me back then—when I was just beginning my work as a CD. The presentation will cover a handful of the problems that caught me off guard—the issues that I believe most newly promoted creatives are unprepared to solve.

I’d like to give you sneak peek into a couple of those lessons here today.

Let Go of Your Old Job

The first mistake I made as a Creative Director was thinking that my job was to be the organization’s uberdesigner. I thought that, as the creative team’s leader, my role was to directly shape, if not outright produce, every aspect of my team’s output. It seems ridiculous to me now, but in those first few months as a CD, I honestly believed that I could—that I should—have my hands in every single deliverable that my team produced.

I learned through trial and error that this doesn’t scale. If everything has to go through you, then your team—no matter how large—slows to the pace of one. I also discovered, in a blow to my graphic designer ego, that it torpedoes the quality of the work as well. If everything requires your “touch,” then your team—no matter how diverse, how skilled, how talented—chokes on the constraints of one person’s abilities.

As a CD, I had to let go of my old job—producing the work—and embrace my new job—designing, maintaining, and growing the machine that produces the work. The machine is what I call the people, the processes, and the culture that make up your team.

Hire People Who Scare You

The second mistake I made as a CD was not understanding that the key ingredient to that people + process + culture equation is, of course, people. I discovered that staffing a creative team is a lot like playing a game of Settlers of Catan.

If you’ve ever played, you know that setting up your initial game pieces—deciding where on the board to place your first city and settlement—is by far the most important part of the game. Making good choices at this stage of the game almost guarantees an enjoyable, competitive game for you—no matter how poorly you play from then on. In contrast, making poor choices during set-up all but dooms you—no matter how brilliant your play is afterward.

Hiring is that important to the success of your team—it’s extremely difficult for a manager to turn a mediocre team member into a great one. Scratch that. It’s not difficult, it’s impossible. You can’t will an employee into sustained, exceptional performance. They have to choose that for themselves—and finding someone who has already made that choice is tough, but not nearly as tough as somehow divining which applicants will make that choice sometime in the future.

The simplest way to solve this problem is to hire people that are already better than you. CDs complain that strong talent and experience is hard to find, but in my experience, that’s not the problem—the real roadblock is the CD’s own pride.

It’s tough to hire someone who’s smarter, more talented, hungrier than you. I can tell you from experience—it’s terrifying! You fear that hiring someone like that will expose you. That they’ll make you look bad. Which is true, they will, IF you are still trying to be the uberdesigner. But, if you’ve embraced your new role as the leader of your team, then you’ll discover (like I did) that hiring exceptional talent won’t expose you, it will exalt you.

Of course, these are just two of many lessons I learned during my conversion from designer to CD. If you’d like to hear the rest, please attend my Adobe MAX session, “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

title: Empowering Creatives is the Key to Collaborative Culture & Brand Growth
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Technology can speed up teams, reduce stress, and help creatives focus on making beautiful work.
content:
This post was written by Andrew Filev, Founder and CEO of Wrike. Wrike is a 2016 MAX partner. We’d like to thank all of our 2016 MAX partners who help make the conference possible.

At Wrike, we try to be a different than other work management software. We’ve always believed that creatives are the strongest drivers of culture and positivity within a company, and have tried to build our tool around creative collaboration since our very early days.

We also believe that teamwork tools should be about building great teams as much as they are about producing great work. People have told me that they feel like close friends with their remote colleagues they’ve never met in person, just because they have such great interactions in Wrike. That’s the result of putting effort into building a tool that fosters spontaneous collaboration, friendly discussions, and risk-free ideation.

That’s why we’re excited to be making our debut at Adobe MAX this year. Since our launch in 2007, we’ve held the philosophy that the key to brand growth lies in eliminating the distractions that too often come between imagination and creation. In short, we believe the key to a successful brand lies in letting creatives be creative.

It’s that philosophy that led us to launch our solution for creatives earlier this year. By integrating tools like image proofing, an Adobe Creative Cloud integration, and project management with a powerful social collaboration tool, we empower creatives to make work that is beautiful and impactful with less stress and confusion.

It’s not easy to challenge what has been the status quo of creative work for almost 20 years, and designing a new way for the world to work requires plenty of imagination. It also takes great care to make sure we’re improving what’s broken without breaking what works for your team. It’s worth it, because email is a 40-year-old technology that is not optimized for the speed needed in today’s creative development cycles. Creatives need tools that allow organized conversations, clear approvals, and the mobility to share ideas wherever they strike.

I founded Wrike 10 years ago with the goal of making teams insanely productive. If I had to revise that now, I’d say, “insanely productive and creative.” The two go hand-in-hand as far as I’m concerned, because creativity is a critical part of making sure you’re standing out from the crowd and innovating in your job – whatever it is.

We’re excited to meet you at MAX. Please swing by the Wrike booth, say hello, and tell us why you love being a brilliant creative.

Andrew Filev, Founder and CEO of Wrike

title: Spark at MAX: Helping Creative Professionals and Small Businesses Stand Out on Social Media
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: You probably know that Adobe MAX is the ultimate place for independent creative pros and small creative shops to learn about the latest professional Adobe tools and techniques for design, photography, and web and video production. But did you also know that, this year at MAX, you can also learn some extremely simple yet powerful new ways to promote your work and tell your stories?
content:
You probably know that Adobe MAX is the ultimate place for independent creative pros and small creative shops to learn about the latest professional Adobe tools and techniques for design, photography, and web and video production. But did you also know that, this year at MAX, you can also learn some extremely simple yet powerful new ways to promote your work and tell your stories?

Compelling communications in minutes

New this year, come see Adobe Spark in action in the Community Pavilion. Adobe Spark helps busy creatives attract audiences and customers on social media with quick and easy ways to turn ideas and messages into beautiful, attention-grabbing social graphics, web stories, and animated videos.

  • Use the free Spark Post to showcase your photography, illustrations, and other creative work in great-looking social media graphics. Bring together stylist text and images to advertise your services, announce an event, or promote an offer in just minutes. For example here:

  • With the free Spark Page, you can give your audiences more in-depth information about your work and business in a visually engaging way. Professional photographers and filmmakers are already using Page to attract new customers and stay connected to existing ones. Photographer and photography instructor Rikk Flor recently used Spark Page to detail his editing process on mobile devices. Photographer Marty Cohen has created photo essays and presentations to showcase his work. And Sundance-winning filmmaker Jim Cummings created a Page about the making of his movie Thunder Road to help spread the word about the film.

  • And with the free Spark Video, you can use your voice and images to tell your stories in simple videos that pack a punch. For example, entrepreneur Christina Swanson has used Spark Video to share tips with other business owners to help them avoid burnout and be more successful. Joe Dockery also used Spark Video for his tutorial on Font Structure:

Step up your social game

Need some ideas and inspiration to see how to promote your work and services more effectively on social media? Be sure to attend these great sessions at MAX:

·      Be Your Own Marketer and Expand Your Social Footprint        

Learn how to apply the same creativity you put into your work to your online marketing strategy. Join Spark Product Marketing Manager Thibault Imbert for an interactive session on how to expand your social footprint, apply growth hacks to your social networks to get your work in front of the right people, and organically grow a community around what you love.

·      Leveraging Social Media to Build Your Brand

Want to use social media to grow your brand but not sure which app to use or how best to use it? Join filmmaker and YouTube creator Sara Dietschy for an overview of multiple social media platforms, including tips on when and how to use each one.

·      Building the Life and Career You Want with Social Media

Leverage the power of social media to share your work, build a following, and monetize your passion. Join photographer Lindsay Adler as she reveals her experiences growing her career in tandem with a social media following. You’ll learn best practices to boost your online presence as a visual artist, attract followers, and build a robust community engaged and invested in your vision.

Hope you stop by to say hi in the Community Pavilion. In the meantime, explore the many ways you can use Spark to create unique social marketing communications in our Inspiration Gallery or follow us @AdobeSpark on social.

content:

title: Sign Up for the Image Imaginarium Preconference at MAX
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Calling all designers, photographers, educators, artists and photo-enthusiasts looking for new and creative ways to express your creativity. We have a few open spots in a brand new pre-conference at MAX, Image Imaginarium.
content:
Calling all designers, photographers, educators, artists and photo-enthusiasts looking for new and creative ways to express your creativity. We have a few open spots in a brand new pre-conference at MAX, Image Imaginarium, brought to you by the same artists that provided the Tintype Booth in the Adobe Make It Experience at MAX last year.

Led by artist Bonny Lhokta and multidisciplinary artist, Jake Weien. This is a unique hands-on experience focused on creating and taking images from analogue to digital. Participants will walk away with several prints to bring home. Prints will be done on metal, wood, plastic, paper or other materials.

This is your chance to untether yourself from your computers and dive back into the real word by using hand made objects, layering and other techniques to simulate what can be done on a machine for image making. The goal is to broaden creative thinking and find new ways to express your ideas.

In this hands-on workshop, you will:

  • Create one-of-a-kind works of art that will transfer onto canvas, metal or hard-plastic
  • Learn to focus on and immerse yourself in the creative process before you snap the shot
  • Create your own analogue filters
  • Expand your techniques and Adobe mobile app knowledge

Preconferences are your chance to stretch your creative muscles outside of the confines of work, and focus on exploring your creative impulses, and this one is particularly unique. If you’re thinking about signing up for a MAX preconference to kick off your conference experience, we highly suggest you give this one a try.

Sign up today by clicking here. 

We’ll see you at MAX!

title: Behind the Scenes at Mama’s Sauce Print Shop
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: We thought we’d give you a behind the scenes look at the Mama’s Sauce print shop – so that you could see the entire digital to analogue experience and get a feel for how things are done. Take a look at the video from our friends there.
content:
Designers are a group known for their passion for print. For many, few things are more exciting than unwrapping the package from the print shop to see their design finalized for the first time. It can be seriously rewarding to feel the weight and cut of the paper, smell the fresh ink and finally hold it in their hands. It’s important to work with a print shop that knows their stuff, and Mama’s Sauce is one that comes highly recommended.

Mama’s Sauce is a boutique spot-color shop that specializes in custom printing on letterpress, screenprint and hot foil. They’re trusted by some of our favorite designers around the world, and last year, they set up shop at Adobe MAX for the first time.

We’re excited to welcome them back to the pavilion floor this year, where they’ll open up both letterpress and screenprint stations to the MAX attendees. What will you be able to print onsite? You’ll have to join us at MAX to find out. You can also join their founder, Nick Sambrato, for his MAX session, Ten Designers That Changed My Life, where he’ll discuss the print projects that helped shape his passion and career.

We thought we’d give you a behind the scenes look at the Mama’s Sauce print shop – so that you could see the entire digital to analogue experience and get a feel for how things are done. Take a look at the video from our friends there:

title: 10 Tips To Help You Get The Most Out Of Attending Adobe MAX From Workgroups DaVinci
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Here are 10 tips to enhance your experience at Adobe MAX and other conferences.
content:
This post is in partnership with 2016 MAX sponsor, Workgroups DaVinci.

Workgroups DaVinci is the only workflow management software designed to drive results. Trusted by brands such as Ralph Lauren, Merck, IKEA and 3M, we arm leaders with the tools to get their marketing and creative teams working smarter, faster and more effectively.

Preparing for, traveling to, and attending a conference like Adobe MAX can often be a challenge to even the most well-organized among us. A little bit of planning in advance, however, goes a long way to ensuring that you get the most value possible from your registration fee and the time you spend in sessions and walking the exhibition floor. Here are 10 tips to enhance your experience at Adobe MAX and other conferences.

BEFORE

Do your homework

Don’t wait until you’ve arrived to start figuring out your conference agenda. Preparation is the most important aspect of attending a conference or tradeshow. Research where the event is (San Diego has so much to be offer!), who will be speaking, which vendors will be there and if anyone in your network will be in attendance. Decide on which sessions you’ll attend in advance and make an effort to connect with relevant speakers and exhibitors on social media beforehand.

Pack accordingly

Little things like showing up with a wrinkled shirt or forgetting to bring your business cards can easily sour your conference experience. Before you pack, make a checklist with important items like nice walking shoes, your business cards, an umbrella, your phone charger, etc. so you won’t be scrambling to replace forgotten items after arrival. Missing the Quentin Tarantino keynote because you need to run out to get band-aids or contact solution is not a position you want to be in.

Set goals

Before you hand over your registration fee, figure out what you’re hoping to get out of attending a particular conference – be as specific as possible. Whether it’s connecting with a certain speaker, learning new tips and techniques to help you in your work or expanding your LinkedIn connections, knowing what you want to accomplish will help you prioritize your time.

DURING

Read the conference program

Instead of ignoring it, page through the program. Even if you’ve already thoroughly checked out the conference website, the program is likely to include helpful information — a map of the venue, info on discounts and giveaways from conference sponsors and suggestions for local attractions, for example — that may not be available online. Don’t forget to check out the daily MAX e-newsletter, too.

Don’t take other work with you

Tempting as it is to bring projects in progress with you, you’ll get more out of Adobe Max if you focus 100% of your energy on the event. Worrying about what you have to do when you get back or even working during the conference will only distract you from potential networking opportunities and the great speakers.

Aim to connect with those in close proximity

When you settle in for a speaker, chances are someone is sitting on either side of you, so make an effort to introduce yourself before the presentation starts or during a break. You never know what opportunities could arise from a simple introduction.

Schedule some free time

Overscheduling is a great way to exhaust yourself – as anyone who has ever tried to see and do it all on a family vacation can attest. Block out time in your conference schedule each day where you can relax with a cup of coffee, network with some newfound friends or just put your feet up in your hotel room for a few minutes to recharge.

AFTER

Follow up

Every person you had a memorable conversation with should receive a personalized follow-up email. This is especially crucial if you were at the conference to identify sales prospects or new business connections. Don’t forget to reach out via LinkedIn to anyone you’d like to make room for in your network.

Review your notes

Of course you took notes on the MAX sessions you attended and your overall thoughts, right? It’s now time to review them. Did you hear about a great new productivity tool that you’re dying to try out? Jot down the name of a speaker’s book you’d like to pick up? Get some tips for streamlining your own creative process? Go through your notes and pull out those action items you want to address now that you’re back home.

Reflect on your goals

Take time to decompress after the conference and think about what you did successfully and what you might want to work on – better prep, more time for networking, remembering that contact solution, etc.– for the next conference.

title: Two Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.
content:
Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.

Over the first decade and a half of my career in design, I’ve worked in a variety of positions across multiple industries in a range of companies. So when I was offered the position of Creative Director at Workfront, I thought I was ready. I was confident that my experience as a designer had prepared me for the role I was about to step into.

Within a couple of weeks on the job, I came to a gut-punch realization: I was not ready. I was SO not ready. Not because I didn’t know my craft—but because I mistakenly believed that the craft was all I needed.

I’m speaking at Adobe MAX in November about some of the painful lessons I’ve learned over the last four years working as a Creative Director in a presentation called “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

My aim is to give the presentation that I wish someone had given to me back then—when I was just beginning my work as a CD. The presentation will cover a handful of the problems that caught me off guard—the issues that I believe most newly promoted creatives are unprepared to solve.

I’d like to give you sneak peek into a couple of those lessons here today.

Let Go of Your Old Job

The first mistake I made as a Creative Director was thinking that my job was to be the organization’s uberdesigner. I thought that, as the creative team’s leader, my role was to directly shape, if not outright produce, every aspect of my team’s output. It seems ridiculous to me now, but in those first few months as a CD, I honestly believed that I could—that I should—have my hands in every single deliverable that my team produced.

I learned through trial and error that this doesn’t scale. If everything has to go through you, then your team—no matter how large—slows to the pace of one. I also discovered, in a blow to my graphic designer ego, that it torpedoes the quality of the work as well. If everything requires your “touch,” then your team—no matter how diverse, how skilled, how talented—chokes on the constraints of one person’s abilities.

As a CD, I had to let go of my old job—producing the work—and embrace my new job—designing, maintaining, and growing the machine that produces the work. The machine is what I call the people, the processes, and the culture that make up your team.

Hire People Who Scare You

The second mistake I made as a CD was not understanding that the key ingredient to that people + process + culture equation is, of course, people. I discovered that staffing a creative team is a lot like playing a game of Settlers of Catan.

If you’ve ever played, you know that setting up your initial game pieces—deciding where on the board to place your first city and settlement—is by far the most important part of the game. Making good choices at this stage of the game almost guarantees an enjoyable, competitive game for you—no matter how poorly you play from then on. In contrast, making poor choices during set-up all but dooms you—no matter how brilliant your play is afterward.

Hiring is that important to the success of your team—it’s extremely difficult for a manager to turn a mediocre team member into a great one. Scratch that. It’s not difficult, it’s impossible. You can’t will an employee into sustained, exceptional performance. They have to choose that for themselves—and finding someone who has already made that choice is tough, but not nearly as tough as somehow divining which applicants will make that choice sometime in the future.

The simplest way to solve this problem is to hire people that are already better than you. CDs complain that strong talent and experience is hard to find, but in my experience, that’s not the problem—the real roadblock is the CD’s own pride.

It’s tough to hire someone who’s smarter, more talented, hungrier than you. I can tell you from experience—it’s terrifying! You fear that hiring someone like that will expose you. That they’ll make you look bad. Which is true, they will, IF you are still trying to be the uberdesigner. But, if you’ve embraced your new role as the leader of your team, then you’ll discover (like I did) that hiring exceptional talent won’t expose you, it will exalt you.

Of course, these are just two of many lessons I learned during my conversion from designer to CD. If you’d like to hear the rest, please attend my Adobe MAX session, “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

title: Sign Up for the Image Imaginarium Preconference at MAX
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Calling all designers, photographers, educators, artists and photo-enthusiasts looking for new and creative ways to express your creativity. We have a few open spots in a brand new pre-conference at MAX, Image Imaginarium.
content:
Calling all designers, photographers, educators, artists and photo-enthusiasts looking for new and creative ways to express your creativity. We have a few open spots in a brand new pre-conference at MAX, Image Imaginarium, brought to you by the same artists that provided the Tintype Booth in the Adobe Make It Experience at MAX last year.

Led by artist Bonny Lhokta and multidisciplinary artist, Jake Weien. This is a unique hands-on experience focused on creating and taking images from analogue to digital. Participants will walk away with several prints to bring home. Prints will be done on metal, wood, plastic, paper or other materials.

This is your chance to untether yourself from your computers and dive back into the real word by using hand made objects, layering and other techniques to simulate what can be done on a machine for image making. The goal is to broaden creative thinking and find new ways to express your ideas.

In this hands-on workshop, you will:

  • Create one-of-a-kind works of art that will transfer onto canvas, metal or hard-plastic
  • Learn to focus on and immerse yourself in the creative process before you snap the shot
  • Create your own analogue filters
  • Expand your techniques and Adobe mobile app knowledge

Preconferences are your chance to stretch your creative muscles outside of the confines of work, and focus on exploring your creative impulses, and this one is particularly unique. If you’re thinking about signing up for a MAX preconference to kick off your conference experience, we highly suggest you give this one a try.

Sign up today by clicking here. 

We’ll see you at MAX!

title: 10 Tips To Help You Get The Most Out Of Attending Adobe MAX From Workgroups DaVinci
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Here are 10 tips to enhance your experience at Adobe MAX and other conferences.
content:
This post is in partnership with 2016 MAX sponsor, Workgroups DaVinci.

Workgroups DaVinci is the only workflow management software designed to drive results. Trusted by brands such as Ralph Lauren, Merck, IKEA and 3M, we arm leaders with the tools to get their marketing and creative teams working smarter, faster and more effectively.

Preparing for, traveling to, and attending a conference like Adobe MAX can often be a challenge to even the most well-organized among us. A little bit of planning in advance, however, goes a long way to ensuring that you get the most value possible from your registration fee and the time you spend in sessions and walking the exhibition floor. Here are 10 tips to enhance your experience at Adobe MAX and other conferences.

BEFORE

Do your homework

Don’t wait until you’ve arrived to start figuring out your conference agenda. Preparation is the most important aspect of attending a conference or tradeshow. Research where the event is (San Diego has so much to be offer!), who will be speaking, which vendors will be there and if anyone in your network will be in attendance. Decide on which sessions you’ll attend in advance and make an effort to connect with relevant speakers and exhibitors on social media beforehand.

Pack accordingly

Little things like showing up with a wrinkled shirt or forgetting to bring your business cards can easily sour your conference experience. Before you pack, make a checklist with important items like nice walking shoes, your business cards, an umbrella, your phone charger, etc. so you won’t be scrambling to replace forgotten items after arrival. Missing the Quentin Tarantino keynote because you need to run out to get band-aids or contact solution is not a position you want to be in.

Set goals

Before you hand over your registration fee, figure out what you’re hoping to get out of attending a particular conference – be as specific as possible. Whether it’s connecting with a certain speaker, learning new tips and techniques to help you in your work or expanding your LinkedIn connections, knowing what you want to accomplish will help you prioritize your time.

DURING

Read the conference program

Instead of ignoring it, page through the program. Even if you’ve already thoroughly checked out the conference website, the program is likely to include helpful information — a map of the venue, info on discounts and giveaways from conference sponsors and suggestions for local attractions, for example — that may not be available online. Don’t forget to check out the daily MAX e-newsletter, too.

Don’t take other work with you

Tempting as it is to bring projects in progress with you, you’ll get more out of Adobe Max if you focus 100% of your energy on the event. Worrying about what you have to do when you get back or even working during the conference will only distract you from potential networking opportunities and the great speakers.

Aim to connect with those in close proximity

When you settle in for a speaker, chances are someone is sitting on either side of you, so make an effort to introduce yourself before the presentation starts or during a break. You never know what opportunities could arise from a simple introduction.

Schedule some free time

Overscheduling is a great way to exhaust yourself – as anyone who has ever tried to see and do it all on a family vacation can attest. Block out time in your conference schedule each day where you can relax with a cup of coffee, network with some newfound friends or just put your feet up in your hotel room for a few minutes to recharge.

AFTER

Follow up

Every person you had a memorable conversation with should receive a personalized follow-up email. This is especially crucial if you were at the conference to identify sales prospects or new business connections. Don’t forget to reach out via LinkedIn to anyone you’d like to make room for in your network.

Review your notes

Of course you took notes on the MAX sessions you attended and your overall thoughts, right? It’s now time to review them. Did you hear about a great new productivity tool that you’re dying to try out? Jot down the name of a speaker’s book you’d like to pick up? Get some tips for streamlining your own creative process? Go through your notes and pull out those action items you want to address now that you’re back home.

Reflect on your goals

Take time to decompress after the conference and think about what you did successfully and what you might want to work on – better prep, more time for networking, remembering that contact solution, etc.– for the next conference.

title: Two Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.
content:
Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.

Over the first decade and a half of my career in design, I’ve worked in a variety of positions across multiple industries in a range of companies. So when I was offered the position of Creative Director at Workfront, I thought I was ready. I was confident that my experience as a designer had prepared me for the role I was about to step into.

Within a couple of weeks on the job, I came to a gut-punch realization: I was not ready. I was SO not ready. Not because I didn’t know my craft—but because I mistakenly believed that the craft was all I needed.

I’m speaking at Adobe MAX in November about some of the painful lessons I’ve learned over the last four years working as a Creative Director in a presentation called “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

My aim is to give the presentation that I wish someone had given to me back then—when I was just beginning my work as a CD. The presentation will cover a handful of the problems that caught me off guard—the issues that I believe most newly promoted creatives are unprepared to solve.

I’d like to give you sneak peek into a couple of those lessons here today.

Let Go of Your Old Job

The first mistake I made as a Creative Director was thinking that my job was to be the organization’s uberdesigner. I thought that, as the creative team’s leader, my role was to directly shape, if not outright produce, every aspect of my team’s output. It seems ridiculous to me now, but in those first few months as a CD, I honestly believed that I could—that I should—have my hands in every single deliverable that my team produced.

I learned through trial and error that this doesn’t scale. If everything has to go through you, then your team—no matter how large—slows to the pace of one. I also discovered, in a blow to my graphic designer ego, that it torpedoes the quality of the work as well. If everything requires your “touch,” then your team—no matter how diverse, how skilled, how talented—chokes on the constraints of one person’s abilities.

As a CD, I had to let go of my old job—producing the work—and embrace my new job—designing, maintaining, and growing the machine that produces the work. The machine is what I call the people, the processes, and the culture that make up your team.

Hire People Who Scare You

The second mistake I made as a CD was not understanding that the key ingredient to that people + process + culture equation is, of course, people. I discovered that staffing a creative team is a lot like playing a game of Settlers of Catan.

If you’ve ever played, you know that setting up your initial game pieces—deciding where on the board to place your first city and settlement—is by far the most important part of the game. Making good choices at this stage of the game almost guarantees an enjoyable, competitive game for you—no matter how poorly you play from then on. In contrast, making poor choices during set-up all but dooms you—no matter how brilliant your play is afterward.

Hiring is that important to the success of your team—it’s extremely difficult for a manager to turn a mediocre team member into a great one. Scratch that. It’s not difficult, it’s impossible. You can’t will an employee into sustained, exceptional performance. They have to choose that for themselves—and finding someone who has already made that choice is tough, but not nearly as tough as somehow divining which applicants will make that choice sometime in the future.

The simplest way to solve this problem is to hire people that are already better than you. CDs complain that strong talent and experience is hard to find, but in my experience, that’s not the problem—the real roadblock is the CD’s own pride.

It’s tough to hire someone who’s smarter, more talented, hungrier than you. I can tell you from experience—it’s terrifying! You fear that hiring someone like that will expose you. That they’ll make you look bad. Which is true, they will, IF you are still trying to be the uberdesigner. But, if you’ve embraced your new role as the leader of your team, then you’ll discover (like I did) that hiring exceptional talent won’t expose you, it will exalt you.

Of course, these are just two of many lessons I learned during my conversion from designer to CD. If you’d like to hear the rest, please attend my Adobe MAX session, “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

title: Empowering Creatives is the Key to Collaborative Culture & Brand Growth
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Technology can speed up teams, reduce stress, and help creatives focus on making beautiful work.
content:
This post was written by Andrew Filev, Founder and CEO of Wrike. Wrike is a 2016 MAX partner. We’d like to thank all of our 2016 MAX partners who help make the conference possible.

At Wrike, we try to be a different than other work management software. We’ve always believed that creatives are the strongest drivers of culture and positivity within a company, and have tried to build our tool around creative collaboration since our very early days.

We also believe that teamwork tools should be about building great teams as much as they are about producing great work. People have told me that they feel like close friends with their remote colleagues they’ve never met in person, just because they have such great interactions in Wrike. That’s the result of putting effort into building a tool that fosters spontaneous collaboration, friendly discussions, and risk-free ideation.

That’s why we’re excited to be making our debut at Adobe MAX this year. Since our launch in 2007, we’ve held the philosophy that the key to brand growth lies in eliminating the distractions that too often come between imagination and creation. In short, we believe the key to a successful brand lies in letting creatives be creative.

It’s that philosophy that led us to launch our solution for creatives earlier this year. By integrating tools like image proofing, an Adobe Creative Cloud integration, and project management with a powerful social collaboration tool, we empower creatives to make work that is beautiful and impactful with less stress and confusion.

It’s not easy to challenge what has been the status quo of creative work for almost 20 years, and designing a new way for the world to work requires plenty of imagination. It also takes great care to make sure we’re improving what’s broken without breaking what works for your team. It’s worth it, because email is a 40-year-old technology that is not optimized for the speed needed in today’s creative development cycles. Creatives need tools that allow organized conversations, clear approvals, and the mobility to share ideas wherever they strike.

I founded Wrike 10 years ago with the goal of making teams insanely productive. If I had to revise that now, I’d say, “insanely productive and creative.” The two go hand-in-hand as far as I’m concerned, because creativity is a critical part of making sure you’re standing out from the crowd and innovating in your job – whatever it is.

We’re excited to meet you at MAX. Please swing by the Wrike booth, say hello, and tell us why you love being a brilliant creative.

Andrew Filev, Founder and CEO of Wrike

title: Spark at MAX: Helping Creative Professionals and Small Businesses Stand Out on Social Media
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: You probably know that Adobe MAX is the ultimate place for independent creative pros and small creative shops to learn about the latest professional Adobe tools and techniques for design, photography, and web and video production. But did you also know that, this year at MAX, you can also learn some extremely simple yet powerful new ways to promote your work and tell your stories?
content:
You probably know that Adobe MAX is the ultimate place for independent creative pros and small creative shops to learn about the latest professional Adobe tools and techniques for design, photography, and web and video production. But did you also know that, this year at MAX, you can also learn some extremely simple yet powerful new ways to promote your work and tell your stories?

Compelling communications in minutes

New this year, come see Adobe Spark in action in the Community Pavilion. Adobe Spark helps busy creatives attract audiences and customers on social media with quick and easy ways to turn ideas and messages into beautiful, attention-grabbing social graphics, web stories, and animated videos.

  • Use the free Spark Post to showcase your photography, illustrations, and other creative work in great-looking social media graphics. Bring together stylist text and images to advertise your services, announce an event, or promote an offer in just minutes. For example here:

  • With the free Spark Page, you can give your audiences more in-depth information about your work and business in a visually engaging way. Professional photographers and filmmakers are already using Page to attract new customers and stay connected to existing ones. Photographer and photography instructor Rikk Flor recently used Spark Page to detail his editing process on mobile devices. Photographer Marty Cohen has created photo essays and presentations to showcase his work. And Sundance-winning filmmaker Jim Cummings created a Page about the making of his movie Thunder Road to help spread the word about the film.

  • And with the free Spark Video, you can use your voice and images to tell your stories in simple videos that pack a punch. For example, entrepreneur Christina Swanson has used Spark Video to share tips with other business owners to help them avoid burnout and be more successful. Joe Dockery also used Spark Video for his tutorial on Font Structure:

Step up your social game

Need some ideas and inspiration to see how to promote your work and services more effectively on social media? Be sure to attend these great sessions at MAX:

·      Be Your Own Marketer and Expand Your Social Footprint        

Learn how to apply the same creativity you put into your work to your online marketing strategy. Join Spark Product Marketing Manager Thibault Imbert for an interactive session on how to expand your social footprint, apply growth hacks to your social networks to get your work in front of the right people, and organically grow a community around what you love.

·      Leveraging Social Media to Build Your Brand

Want to use social media to grow your brand but not sure which app to use or how best to use it? Join filmmaker and YouTube creator Sara Dietschy for an overview of multiple social media platforms, including tips on when and how to use each one.

·      Building the Life and Career You Want with Social Media

Leverage the power of social media to share your work, build a following, and monetize your passion. Join photographer Lindsay Adler as she reveals her experiences growing her career in tandem with a social media following. You’ll learn best practices to boost your online presence as a visual artist, attract followers, and build a robust community engaged and invested in your vision.

Hope you stop by to say hi in the Community Pavilion. In the meantime, explore the many ways you can use Spark to create unique social marketing communications in our Inspiration Gallery or follow us @AdobeSpark on social.

title: Jordan Peele Will Host MAX 2016 Sneaks
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: In a hilarious turn of events, Jordan Peele will take over for Keegan-Michael Key as Adobe MAX 2016 Sneaks Host. We're thrilled he could fill in.
content:
In a hilarious turn of events, Jordan Peele will take over for Keegan-Michael Key as Adobe MAX 2016 Sneaks Host. We’re thrilled he could fill in.

Jordan Peele is the co-star and co-creator of Comedy Central’s Key & Peele, which in 2014 won a Peabody Award and an American Comedy Award for Best Alternative Comedy Series. The show has become a TV and internet sensation with 12 Emmy nominations and over 900 million online hits.

Additionally, Jordan was named among TIME magazine’s “Most Influential People of 2014” and Entertainment Weekly’s “Entertainers of the Year of 2012.” 

If you’re unfamiliar with Sneaks, we’ll give you some background on one of the most popular events at MAX. Sneaks is where we pull back the curtain to give you an inside look into what’s coming down the pipeline in the Adobe development labs. You’ll be the first to see what might (or might not) end up in future products and services. Last year we showed you Monument Mode, Deep Font, and Audio Retargeting, to name just a few. We’ll also serve up some tasty adult beverages that you can enjoy during the show. After that, it’s on to MAX Bash, where you can peruse the food trucks and take in performances by The Mowgli’s and Alabama Shakes.

We’ll see you there!

Did you hear about a great new productivity tool that you’re dying to try out? Jot down the name of a speaker’s book you’d like to pick up? Get some tips for streamlining your own creative process? Go through your notes and pull out those action items you want to address now that you’re back home.

Reflect on your goals

Take time to decompress after the conference and think about what you did successfully and what you might want to work on – better prep, more time for networking, remembering that contact solution, etc.– for the next conference.

title: Two Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.
content:
Adobe is proud to welcome Workfront as 2016 MAX sponsor. Their Creative Director, David Lesue has worked as a graphic designer, UX designer and creative director for more than 15 years. In this post, David shares his top advice for designers making the jump to a creative director position. Be sure to sign up for David’s session at MAX this year – 7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.

Over the first decade and a half of my career in design, I’ve worked in a variety of positions across multiple industries in a range of companies. So when I was offered the position of Creative Director at Workfront, I thought I was ready. I was confident that my experience as a designer had prepared me for the role I was about to step into.

Within a couple of weeks on the job, I came to a gut-punch realization: I was not ready. I was SO not ready. Not because I didn’t know my craft—but because I mistakenly believed that the craft was all I needed.

I’m speaking at Adobe MAX in November about some of the painful lessons I’ve learned over the last four years working as a Creative Director in a presentation called “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

My aim is to give the presentation that I wish someone had given to me back then—when I was just beginning my work as a CD. The presentation will cover a handful of the problems that caught me off guard—the issues that I believe most newly promoted creatives are unprepared to solve.

I’d like to give you sneak peek into a couple of those lessons here today.

Let Go of Your Old Job

The first mistake I made as a Creative Director was thinking that my job was to be the organization’s uberdesigner. I thought that, as the creative team’s leader, my role was to directly shape, if not outright produce, every aspect of my team’s output. It seems ridiculous to me now, but in those first few months as a CD, I honestly believed that I could—that I should—have my hands in every single deliverable that my team produced.

I learned through trial and error that this doesn’t scale. If everything has to go through you, then your team—no matter how large—slows to the pace of one. I also discovered, in a blow to my graphic designer ego, that it torpedoes the quality of the work as well. If everything requires your “touch,” then your team—no matter how diverse, how skilled, how talented—chokes on the constraints of one person’s abilities.

As a CD, I had to let go of my old job—producing the work—and embrace my new job—designing, maintaining, and growing the machine that produces the work. The machine is what I call the people, the processes, and the culture that make up your team.

Hire People Who Scare You

The second mistake I made as a CD was not understanding that the key ingredient to that people + process + culture equation is, of course, people. I discovered that staffing a creative team is a lot like playing a game of Settlers of Catan.

If you’ve ever played, you know that setting up your initial game pieces—deciding where on the board to place your first city and settlement—is by far the most important part of the game. Making good choices at this stage of the game almost guarantees an enjoyable, competitive game for you—no matter how poorly you play from then on. In contrast, making poor choices during set-up all but dooms you—no matter how brilliant your play is afterward.

Hiring is that important to the success of your team—it’s extremely difficult for a manager to turn a mediocre team member into a great one. Scratch that. It’s not difficult, it’s impossible. You can’t will an employee into sustained, exceptional performance. They have to choose that for themselves—and finding someone who has already made that choice is tough, but not nearly as tough as somehow divining which applicants will make that choice sometime in the future.

The simplest way to solve this problem is to hire people that are already better than you. CDs complain that strong talent and experience is hard to find, but in my experience, that’s not the problem—the real roadblock is the CD’s own pride.

It’s tough to hire someone who’s smarter, more talented, hungrier than you. I can tell you from experience—it’s terrifying! You fear that hiring someone like that will expose you. That they’ll make you look bad. Which is true, they will, IF you are still trying to be the uberdesigner. But, if you’ve embraced your new role as the leader of your team, then you’ll discover (like I did) that hiring exceptional talent won’t expose you, it will exalt you.

Of course, these are just two of many lessons I learned during my conversion from designer to CD. If you’d like to hear the rest, please attend my Adobe MAX session, “7 Things Every Designer Should Know Before Becoming a Creative Director.”

title: Empowering Creatives is the Key to Collaborative Culture & Brand Growth
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Technology can speed up teams, reduce stress, and help creatives focus on making beautiful work.
content:
This post was written by Andrew Filev, Founder and CEO of Wrike. Wrike is a 2016 MAX partner. We’d like to thank all of our 2016 MAX partners who help make the conference possible.

At Wrike, we try to be a different than other work management software. We’ve always believed that creatives are the strongest drivers of culture and positivity within a company, and have tried to build our tool around creative collaboration since our very early days.

We also believe that teamwork tools should be about building great teams as much as they are about producing great work. People have told me that they feel like close friends with their remote colleagues they’ve never met in person, just because they have such great interactions in Wrike. That’s the result of putting effort into building a tool that fosters spontaneous collaboration, friendly discussions, and risk-free ideation.

That’s why we’re excited to be making our debut at Adobe MAX this year. Since our launch in 2007, we’ve held the philosophy that the key to brand growth lies in eliminating the distractions that too often come between imagination and creation. In short, we believe the key to a successful brand lies in letting creatives be creative.

It’s that philosophy that led us to launch our solution for creatives earlier this year. By integrating tools like image proofing, an Adobe Creative Cloud integration, and project management with a powerful social collaboration tool, we empower creatives to make work that is beautiful and impactful with less stress and confusion.

It’s not easy to challenge what has been the status quo of creative work for almost 20 years, and designing a new way for the world to work requires plenty of imagination. It also takes great care to make sure we’re improving what’s broken without breaking what works for your team. It’s worth it, because email is a 40-year-old technology that is not optimized for the speed needed in today’s creative development cycles. Creatives need tools that allow organized conversations, clear approvals, and the mobility to share ideas wherever they strike.

I founded Wrike 10 years ago with the goal of making teams insanely productive. If I had to revise that now, I’d say, “insanely productive and creative.” The two go hand-in-hand as far as I’m concerned, because creativity is a critical part of making sure you’re standing out from the crowd and innovating in your job – whatever it is.

We’re excited to meet you at MAX. Please swing by the Wrike booth, say hello, and tell us why you love being a brilliant creative.

Andrew Filev, Founder and CEO of Wrike

title: Spark at MAX: Helping Creative Professionals and Small Businesses Stand Out on Social Media
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: You probably know that Adobe MAX is the ultimate place for independent creative pros and small creative shops to learn about the latest professional Adobe tools and techniques for design, photography, and web and video production. But did you also know that, this year at MAX, you can also learn some extremely simple yet powerful new ways to promote your work and tell your stories?
content:
You probably know that Adobe MAX is the ultimate place for independent creative pros and small creative shops to learn about the latest professional Adobe tools and techniques for design, photography, and web and video production. But did you also know that, this year at MAX, you can also learn some extremely simple yet powerful new ways to promote your work and tell your stories?

Compelling communications in minutes

New this year, come see Adobe Spark in action in the Community Pavilion. Adobe Spark helps busy creatives attract audiences and customers on social media with quick and easy ways to turn ideas and messages into beautiful, attention-grabbing social graphics, web stories, and animated videos.

  • Use the free Spark Post to showcase your photography, illustrations, and other creative work in great-looking social media graphics. Bring together stylist text and images to advertise your services, announce an event, or promote an offer in just minutes. For example here:

  • With the free Spark Page, you can give your audiences more in-depth information about your work and business in a visually engaging way. Professional photographers and filmmakers are already using Page to attract new customers and stay connected to existing ones. Photographer and photography instructor Rikk Flor recently used Spark Page to detail his editing process on mobile devices. Photographer Marty Cohen has created photo essays and presentations to showcase his work. And Sundance-winning filmmaker Jim Cummings created a Page about the making of his movie Thunder Road to help spread the word about the film.

  • And with the free Spark Video, you can use your voice and images to tell your stories in simple videos that pack a punch. For example, entrepreneur Christina Swanson has used Spark Video to share tips with other business owners to help them avoid burnout and be more successful. Joe Dockery also used Spark Video for his tutorial on Font Structure:

Step up your social game

Need some ideas and inspiration to see how to promote your work and services more effectively on social media? Be sure to attend these great sessions at MAX:

·      Be Your Own Marketer and Expand Your Social Footprint        

Learn how to apply the same creativity you put into your work to your online marketing strategy. Join Spark Product Marketing Manager Thibault Imbert for an interactive session on how to expand your social footprint, apply growth hacks to your social networks to get your work in front of the right people, and organically grow a community around what you love.

·      Leveraging Social Media to Build Your Brand

Want to use social media to grow your brand but not sure which app to use or how best to use it? Join filmmaker and YouTube creator Sara Dietschy for an overview of multiple social media platforms, including tips on when and how to use each one.

·      Building the Life and Career You Want with Social Media

Leverage the power of social media to share your work, build a following, and monetize your passion. Join photographer Lindsay Adler as she reveals her experiences growing her career in tandem with a social media following. You’ll learn best practices to boost your online presence as a visual artist, attract followers, and build a robust community engaged and invested in your vision.

Hope you stop by to say hi in the Community Pavilion. In the meantime, explore the many ways you can use Spark to create unique social marketing communications in our Inspiration Gallery or follow us @AdobeSpark on social.

title: Jordan Peele Will Host MAX 2016 Sneaks
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: In a hilarious turn of events, Jordan Peele will take over for Keegan-Michael Key as Adobe MAX 2016 Sneaks Host. We're thrilled he could fill in.
content:
In a hilarious turn of events, Jordan Peele will take over for Keegan-Michael Key as Adobe MAX 2016 Sneaks Host. We’re thrilled he could fill in.

Jordan Peele is the co-star and co-creator of Comedy Central’s Key & Peele, which in 2014 won a Peabody Award and an American Comedy Award for Best Alternative Comedy Series. The show has become a TV and internet sensation with 12 Emmy nominations and over 900 million online hits.

Additionally, Jordan was named among TIME magazine’s “Most Influential People of 2014” and Entertainment Weekly’s “Entertainers of the Year of 2012.” 

If you’re unfamiliar with Sneaks, we’ll give you some background on one of the most popular events at MAX. Sneaks is where we pull back the curtain to give you an inside look into what’s coming down the pipeline in the Adobe development labs. You’ll be the first to see what might (or might not) end up in future products and services. Last year we showed you Monument Mode, Deep Font, and Audio Retargeting, to name just a few. We’ll also serve up some tasty adult beverages that you can enjoy during the show. After that, it’s on to MAX Bash, where you can peruse the food trucks and take in performances by The Mowgli’s and Alabama Shakes.

We’ll see you there!

title: Quentin Tarantino joins Day 2 Keynote Speakers for MAX
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Just announced! Adobe will welcome renowned film director and writer Quentin Tarantino as an Adobe MAX keynote speaker.
content:
Just announced! Adobe will welcome renowned film director and writer Quentin Tarantino as an Adobe MAX keynote speaker for day two of the conference, where he will be interviewed by Adobe’s Chief Marketing Officer, Ann Lewnes.

Tarantino is well known for his many films, including Reservoir Dogs, Pulp Fiction, the Kill Bill movies, Django Unchained, and most recently, The Hateful Eight.

We’re excited to welcome Tarantino to MAX, and we hope that you can join us in San Diego to see all our 2016 speakers, and attend an array of sessions, labs and workshops that will enable your creative career. Check out more about Adobe MAX here.

title: Sign Up for the Image Imaginarium Preconference at MAX
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: Calling all designers, photographers, educators, artists and photo-enthusiasts looking for new and creative ways to express your creativity. We have a few open spots in a brand new pre-conference at MAX, Image Imaginarium.
content:
Calling all designers, photographers, educators, artists and photo-enthusiasts looking for new and creative ways to express your creativity. We have a few open spots in a brand new pre-conference at MAX, Image Imaginarium, brought to you by the same artists that provided the Tintype Booth in the Adobe Make It Experience at MAX last year.

Led by artist Bonny Lhokta and multidisciplinary artist, Jake Weien. This is a unique hands-on experience focused on creating and taking images from analogue to digital. Participants will walk away with several prints to bring home. Prints will be done on metal, wood, plastic, paper or other materials.

This is your chance to untether yourself from your computers and dive back into the real word by using hand made objects, layering and other techniques to simulate what can be done on a machine for image making. The goal is to broaden creative thinking and find new ways to express your ideas.

In this hands-on workshop, you will:

  • Create one-of-a-kind works of art that will transfer onto canvas, metal or hard-plastic
  • Learn to focus on and immerse yourself in the creative process before you snap the shot
  • Create your own analogue filters
  • Expand your techniques and Adobe mobile app knowledge

Preconferences are your chance to stretch your creative muscles outside of the confines of work, and focus on exploring your creative impulses, and this one is particularly unique. If you’re thinking about signing up for a MAX preconference to kick off your conference experience, we highly suggest you give this one a try.

Sign up today by clicking here. 

We’ll see you at MAX!

title: Behind the Scenes at Mama’s Sauce Print Shop
author: Elissa Dunn Scott
summary: We thought we’d give you a behind the scenes look at the Mama’s Sauce print shop – so that you could see the entire digital to analogue experience and get a feel for how things are done. Take a look at the video from our friends there.
content:
Designers are a group known for their passion for print. For many, few things are more exciting than unwrapping the package from the print shop to see their design finalized for the first time. It can be seriously rewarding to feel the weight and cut of the paper, smell the fresh ink and finally hold it in their hands. It’s important to work with a print shop that knows their stuff, and Mama’s Sauce is one that comes highly recommended.

Mama’s Sauce is a boutique spot-color shop that specializes in custom printing on letterpress, screenprint and hot foil. They’re trusted by some of our favorite designers around the world, and last year, they set up shop at Adobe MAX for the first time.

We’re excited to welcome them back to the pavilion floor this year, where they’ll open up both letterpress and screenprint stations to the MAX attendees. What will you be able to print onsite? You’ll have to join us at MAX to find out. You can also join their founder, Nick Sambrato, for his MAX session, Ten Designers That Changed My Life, where he’ll discuss the print projects that helped shape his passion and career.

We thought we’d give you a behind the scenes look at the Mama’s Sauce print shop – so that you could see the entire digital to analogue experience and get a feel for how things are done. Take a look at the video from our friends there:
